article.title: The Smith normal form of a specialized Giambelli-type matrix

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this formula represent?   Φε δλ = Π (t + c(i, j))                             (i,j) Ελ                             h(i, j)
choices: The determinant of a specialized Jacobi-Trudi matrix.
The hook-content formula for a Schur function.
The Frobenius notation of a partition.
The definition of a Giambelli-type matrix.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this equation describe?  μ(k,+) = UDe(x)−1+1           l=1           k
choices: The content of a cell in a Young diagram.
The hook decomposition of a partition μ(k,+).
The calculation of a skew Schur function.
The diagonal entries of a Smith normal form.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the context of analyzing the Giambelli matrix, what does this equation represent? μ(k) = UDr-l+1       l=1       k
choices: The content of the cells in a diagonal hook.
The hook decomposition of the partition represented by a submatrix.
The calculation of the determinant of a specialized Giambelli matrix.
The Frobenius notation of a partition.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of this equation in the context of q-analogues? φυλ = ((1-q)y+1)^(|λ|) * φ*sλ = q^(Σ(k-1)λk)  Π  ((y + c(i,j))/(h(i,j))                                                 (i,j) Ελ
choices: It defines a q-analogue of the hook-content formula.
It provides a way to calculate the Smith normal form of a q-analogue of a Jacobi-Trudi matrix.
It defines a map that leads to a q-analogue of the Schur function specialization.
It calculates the determinant of a q-analogue of a Giambelli-type matrix.
